Award.AwardTitle: REU Site: Networking Basic Research for Biological Discovery
Award.AbstractNarration:
This REU Site Award to the Wadsworth Center, New York State Department of Health, located in Albany, NY, will support the training of 10 students for 10 weeks during the summers of 2014-2016. The primary objective of this program is to provide cutting-edge research experiences by networking undergraduate students with each other and with their mentors to gain insight into how modern scientific research is conducted. The Wadsworth Center provides outstanding basic research and graduate education programs paralleling public health activities. Mentors have diverse research interests in molecular genetics, cell biology, structural and computational biology, and the environmental sciences. Applicants will be recruited nationally and students from all majors are eligible to apply. Students can join either a traditional, single-mentored research project, or a collaborative project in which two students are networked to tackle a common research problem. The research program will be supplemented by weekly seminars given by visiting scientists and Wadsworth faculty. In addition, the Wadsworth Site will provide students with a strong background in the ethical conduct of research, career planning, the modern history of science, and a unique perspective on how research is translated to public policy.

Candidates will be selected based on personal essay, two letters of recommendation, research interests, and academic performance. Students with limited research opportunities at their home institution and those from underrepresented groups are encouraged to apply. All research activities are pursued within a close-knit environment that will provide an uniquely enriching research training opportunity. During the final week, students will present their research at a symposium that will be video-cast throughout Wadsworth and recorded to improve communication skills. Students will also be encouraged to present the results of their work at scientific conferences.

Program evaluation will be facilitated by using the Bio REU common assessment survey and the SURE survey. Students are required to be tracked after the program and must respond to an automatic e-mail sent via the NSF reporting system. More information is available by contacting reu@health.ny.gov.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The Wadsworth Center’s REU site award, “Networking Basic Research for Biological Discovery,” was designed to support an immersive, 10-week research program for talented undergraduates with limited research opportunities at their home institutions. The intellectual focus was on collaborative biological research in cutting-edge scientific laboratories, which allowed the students to experience the application of multiple scientific methods to tackle complex biological research problems. The research projects were carefully designed to be achievable, and yet flexible enough to allow students to generate and test individual hypotheses themselves. The projects spanned a wide range of areas such as molecular genetics, cell biology, neuroscience, and structural and computational biology, thereby collectively providing a broad overview of research in biology to the student group. In addition to laboratory-based research, the program provided training in ethics, responsible conduct of research, seminars from a diverse range of speakers in numerous fields of research, as well as presentation skills. By pairing multiple students with a single mentor, or single students with multiple mentors, the program illustrates how advances in biology come through both individual as well as team based, multi-disciplinary collaborative research.

Over four summers, 33 students were directly supported by this award (including one in a No Cost Extension from our prior award). In addition, 4 students were supported by supplements to NSF grants to their mentors and co-hosted with the REU students, and 33 other summer students were included in the umbrella summer programas well. Five of the site award-supported students have already matriculated to graduate programs, one has been accepted for enrollment this fall, and six are working in science-related jobs. We prioritized recruitment of students without prior research experiences, resulting in 22 students who participated after their freshman or sophomore years in college.  Thus, many of our students have not yet graduated. Post-summer surveys indicate that many of the students desire to obtain advanced degrees in science once their undergraduate studies are complete. Eleven peer-reviewed journal articles have been published that include NSF-supported students as co-authors during the period of the award, and 8 of the students have presented their research at local and/or national conferences. 

Of the 33 students we trained, 15 were under-represented minorities, and an additional seven students were the first in their families to attend college. 24 of our students were from small colleges or universities without major research activities, and 10 were from NYS CSTEP institutions.

Overall, our program has helped develop the next generation of scientists and helped create a well-educated, scientifically-literate citizenry.
